text: As you probably know by now, electronic music production is very complicated, so you might be wondering,
is there a system that you could follow to actually get really good results every time?
Well, I've actually developed a system that has helped my students hit over 100 million streams in multiple genres
and get their music signed to some of the world's biggest labels, and the best thing is you can just copy it.
And this system kind of takes away a lot of the complication. So here's what I want to share with you today.
We're going to go through my perfect DAW template setup. We're going to go through sample organization and favorites.
We're going to go through how to reference and the importance of focus, and we're going to go through mix levels.
We're going to go through arrangement to get out of that eight bar loop, and then we're going to go into some other stuff as well,
like automation. And I want to share all of this with you today because it's actually what we teach in our music production accelerator program.
So if you watch this video and you find it useful and you do want to find out about our coaching program, you can click the link below and check it out.
I've also shared with you this entire system, which you can download in a free cheat sheet below this video as well to help.
OK, so the first thing I want to talk about is the template walkthrough.
So it doesn't matter if you're using Ableton or Logic or FL Studio.
It's important to have a template set up to help you work quickly, because when I started doing this as a full time job,
you're having to produce every day and you want to get things done quickly.
So you're in a state of flow because that's the easiest way to work.
So let me just walk you through what I use for my Ableton setup.
I used to have a really complicated template, but I found it would always kind of push me in a certain direction.
And that's why I simplified this.
So I've got this channel, which is an audio track, and that's for my reference track.
We're going to get to that in section three of this guide today.
And then I've got this SC trigger, which is a sidechain trigger.
Again, we're going to get to that soon.
And then I've got a track set up for my kick drum, a track set up for my other drums and just a blank midi track set up for my bass.
I've also got a few plugins here, which I'm going to walk through as well.
So reference track, I've got this mono switch, which allows me to reduce the volume of my reference track,
which has already been mastered, and it allows me to switch the whole mix into mono, which I'm going to touch upon soon as well.
And then I've got this referencing roll off, which is just an EQ.
It allows me to listen to just the low frequencies or the high frequencies of my reference track.
And then I've got a loudness meter, which allows me to measure the volume or the average volume of that reference track.
And then I've got an EQ, which allows me to just view the frequency spread of the reference track.
So I'm kind of using it like a spectrum analyzer.
And then for the kick drum, I use midi.
Doesn't matter if you use audio.
In fact, audio is probably better in many ways.
And then I've got a drum rack in Ableton.
But again, you can use audio.
It doesn't matter whatever works for you.
And then for my auxiliary channels, I've got a room reverb set up with a very short decay of under half a second.
And then I've got a whole reverb with a longer decay of about five and a half seconds.
But I usually change that.
And I've got this bass reverb channel, which I don't often use, actually.
So I'll get rid of that for now.
And then on our main master channel, I've got another mono switch, which allows us to switch the whole mix into mono.
And then I've got this limiter test, which I don't really use.
And then the referencing roll off so I can compare my tracks to the reference track that I'm going to use as well.
And then I've got a loudness meter and a spectrum analyzer on the end, exactly the same as I have on my reference channel.
Finally, I've got my reference track set up to go to external out, so it doesn't go through into my main master channel.
And that's pretty much it.
I really try and keep this as simple as possible because it allows more creativity and flexibility.
But you'll develop your own DAW template over time.
But if you haven't got one, I've included it in the link that's got the cheat sheet to help with this process.
So you'll get that there as well.
Now, let's look at the sample organization favorites, because this is so important.
I've literally worked with thousands of people now.
And one of the things they struggle with most is picking the right sounds.
If you pick the right sounds and you can compose it well, the mixing and the mastering is kind of easy after that point.
So it's really important to organize your samples, spend half a day going through them, selecting your favorites,
invest in a couple of really good sample packs for your chosen genre.
If you pick a couple of good sample packs and you get to know them, you can use those for years.
I've still using samples I've had for probably 15 years now.
So it's really important.
And you can use stuff like Splice as well, of course.
But Splice tends not to organize it that well.
If you can organize them into your favorites, just duplicate the ones you like most.
Don't worry if you've got a couple of duplicates on your hard drive.
A kick drum duplicated twice is not going to take up much memory, you know.
So I've got my favorites.
I've got all of the different categories for drums.
I've got all of the different categories for different sounds.
And that's where I save my favorites.
And that's so every track I start, I know I can reach for some good sounds really quickly.
And my friend Josh, who's got over 100 million streams, will sometimes even start using the same project file as a previous track that he's done.
Delete most of it apart from, for example, the kick and the bass.
And then he's got a solid foundation that he knows works to start his next track.
So now I'm going to put my headphones on and we'll get into the production part of this guide.
And there's one thing that I'm going to show you now that if you get right, is going to absolutely change your life.
And this is all about focus and having reference tracks.
Now, one of the biggest mistakes that I see new producers making, in fact, not even new producers, is that they want to be original before they can actually make something that sounds good.
But for me, this would be like walking into a karate dojo as a white belt and saying to the sensei, you know what?
I'm going to design my own martial art from scratch and it's going to be the best thing ever.
No, you learn the basics, you learn what works, because then once you've learned those rules, you can know how to bend them.
I resisted this for years. I literally resisted this for years.
But when I actually embraced referencing within a week, within a few days, my entire career trajectory changed.
I got my first manager, I got paid for my first remix, and then I started becoming an actual full time music producer.
So please, if you take anything from this guide, let the fact that referencing will help you be that thing.
So I've got this reference track set up and the way to get a good reference track firstly is what music do you like listening to?
What music do you like producing?
Now, for some people, this is really obvious to them.
Other people like myself have a very broad taste.
So I would look at your playlist history and try and find out what you listen to most.
That's a good indication of what you probably like to produce.
And then where do you get your reference tracks?
Just get them from Beatport.
They're really high quality, it costs a couple of pounds.
You'll support the artist, just buy the WAV file if you can, because it's higher quality, although really a 320 kilobits per second MP3 is fine.
Buy it, download it, and now we're going to bring it into my project file and I'm going to show you exactly how to use it.
Now, before you start complaining and say, oh, Will, I want to create something completely original and for the world to see my beautiful creativity,
I'm going to show you how you're going to create something original from this.
So don't worry, but it all starts with referencing.

So we're not going to run into clipping issues ourselves.
That is exactly what this first thing's for, where I take it down by 12 decibels.

This is when you can also use your reference track to help you map out the arrangement.
So where do the beats come in?
Where's just the top kick playing?
Where does the bass line come in?
Comes in there.

And you go through the whole track and you just map out yours to match the reference track.

You could just replicate the kick and the snare and have it working really well together

You might use one track to help you with the sounds
and then another track to help you with the arrangement.
You can do this as much or as little as you want, but it really helps.
At that point, you'd go into the automation, blending all of those sections together
in what I call the four-dimensional arrangement process,
because you've got the blocks that sound great and then you smooth them together,
again, using the reference track to work out what effects you should be using,
what transitions you can be using before finally going into the mixing and the mastering stage.
